title: RS21424
content: In enacting the CAA of 1970, Congress differentiated between existing and new stationary sources of air pollution. Existing sources were deemed economically and technologically impractical to retrofit with the latest pollution control technology. New sources, however, were required to install state-of-the-art controls to prevent new pollution problems. States had discretion to set emission standards for existing major air pollutants under the CAA of 1970. The CAA of 1970 differentiated between existing and new stationary sources of air pollution. States had discretion to set emission standards for existing major air pollutants, while new sources were required to install state-of-the-art controls to prevent new pollution problems. EPA sets strict technology-based standards for new sources that may endanger public health or welfare. The 1977 amendments to the Clean Air Act gave EPA the authority to set emission standards for new sources of air pollutants that may endanger public health or welfare. These standards, known as NSPSs, are technology-based and require the use of the best demonstrated technology to achieve the emissions rate. In areas with cleaner or dirtier air than national standards, major new sources must undergo NSR before construction. The 1977 amendments to the Clean Air Act introduced NSR requirements for new sources of air pollutants in areas with cleaner or dirtier air than national standards. These requirements mandate obtaining pre-construction permits with emission limits based on "best available control technology" or "lowest achievable emission rate." The new rule allows for the replacement of components under more circumstances than the former case-by-case approach, as long as the cost is less than 20% of the unit's current replacement value and does not change the unit's design parameters.
